verses.text: God is our refuge and strength, an ever-present help in trouble.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 46
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 46 This psalm has some affinities with Ps. 48; 76; 84; and 87, which are called “Zion Songs.” Though Zion is not specifically mentioned, it is alluded to in vv. 4, 5. Martin Luther was moved by this psalm to write the famous hymn, “A Mighty Fortress Is Our God.”

rsbNotes.title: Ps 46:1
rsbNotes.text: 46:1 strength. See “Omnipresence and Omnipotence” at Jer. 23:24.

verses.text: Therefore we will not fear, though the earth give way and the mountains fall into the heart of the sea,
though its waters roar and foam and the mountains quake with their surging. Selah

rsbNotes.title: Ps 46:2
rsbNotes.text: 46:2 the mountains . . . the sea. A violent earthquake is described; there may be ancient Near Eastern portrayals of cosmic violence employed here. God overcomes the sea to accomplish His purposes (cf. Ps. 18; 74; 77; Nah. 1).

verses.text: There is a river whose streams make glad the city of God, the holy place where the Most High dwells.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 46:4
rsbNotes.text:
46:4 a river. Ancient and present Jerusalem have no river. There was a river in Eden (Gen. 2:10), as well as a “river . . . of life” that flows from the throne of God in the New Jerusalem (Rev. 22:1, 2).

the holy habitation. As the Israelites looked to the temple, they felt secure in the symbol of God’s protection. Later in their history the people regarded the temple as a kind of idol that would save them from the Babylonians (Jer. 7). In this psalm, however, their trust is faithful and obedient, prefiguring the security enjoyed by God’s people in the eternal city that is to come (Rev. 22:3).

verses.text: God is within her, she will not fall; God will help her at break of day.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 46:5
rsbNotes.text:
46:5 she shall not be moved. Ancient Jerusalem indeed fell to the Babylonians in 586 b.c. The New Jerusalem will stand “forever and ever” (Rev. 22:5).

when morning dawns. In military campaigns, fighting commenced at first light. God’s help will not be slow.

verses.text: Nations are in uproar, kingdoms fall; he lifts his voice, the earth melts.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 46:6
rsbNotes.text: 46:6 the earth melts. At the voice of God the tumult of the rebellious is stilled forever.

verses.text: The LORD Almighty is with us; the God of Jacob is our fortress. Selah
Come and see the works of the LORD, the desolations he has brought on the earth.
He makes wars cease to the ends of the earth; he breaks the bow and shatters the spear, he burns the shields with fire.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 46:7
rsbNotes.text: 46:7 with us. The refrain (again in v. 11) reflects the consolation of God’s people enjoying His protection.

verses.text: "Be still, and know that I am God; I will be exalted among the nations, I will be exalted in the earth."
The LORD Almighty is with us; the God of Jacob is our fortress. Selah

rsbNotes.title: Ps 46:10
rsbNotes.text: 46:10 Be still. In the true knowledge of God and His deliverance there is peace, in contrast with the troubled “nations” (v. 6).
